summary: This is a memorandum from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York requesting approval under the Hammad rule to interview three inmates as witnesses in the investigation into the circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody. The memo outlines the investigation's focus on BOP staff failures and falsification of records on August 9-10, 2019.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Apparent Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by apparent suicide while in the custody of the Bureau of Prisons at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Failure to Assign Cellmate to Epstein
events.description: MCC staff decided not to reassign a cellmate to Jeffrey Epstein on August 9, 2019, contrary to regular BOP practice and direct orders from the Warden.

events.title: Failure to Perform Overnight Checks
events.description: Correctional officers assigned to the Special Housing Unit where Epstein was housed failed to perform required overnight counts and 30-minute checks on the night of August 9, 2019.

events.title: Falsification of Records
events.description: Records related to count slips and 30-minute checks for Epstein's unit were falsified, in violation of 18 U.S.C. ยง 1519.

keyFacts: The document is a formal request (Hammad Memo) for approval to interview three inmate witnesses regarding Jeffrey Epstein's death.
The investigation focuses on three specific failures by MCC staff: not assigning a cellmate to Epstein as ordered, failing to perform required overnight checks, and falsifying related records.
The three inmates to be interviewed were housed in the same area of the SHU as Epstein on the night of his death and are considered the most likely to have relevant information.
Each of the three inmates is currently being prosecuted by the SDNY for other crimes, but the investigating agents have had no involvement in those cases.
The memo argues the proposed contact is permissible as the inmates are not represented concerning their status as witnesses to Epstein's death, and questioning will be narrowly focused on that event.
